name: Italian Game (Giuoco Piano)
description: One of the oldest chess openings, the Italian Game focuses on rapid development and central control. White develops the Bishop to c4, targeting the weak f7 square.
strategy: Control the center with pawns, develop pieces quickly toward the kingside, prepare for castling. The Bishop on c4 puts pressure on f7, the weakest point in Black's position.

name: Spanish Opening (Ruy Lopez)
description: Named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura, this is one of the most popular and deeply analyzed openings. White's Bishop on b5 puts pressure on the knight defending e5.
strategy: Apply subtle pressure on Black's center by attacking the knight that defends e5. White aims for long-term positional advantage rather than immediate tactics.

name: Sicilian Defense
description: The most popular defense against 1.e4 at all levels. Black immediately fights for the center with c5, creating an asymmetric pawn structure that leads to sharp, dynamic play.
strategy: Black avoids symmetry and aims for counterplay on the queenside while White attacks on the kingside. Leads to rich tactical and strategic battles.

name: French Defense
description: A solid, strategic defense where Black builds a strong pawn chain and controls the center. Named after a Paris match in 1834.
strategy: Black prepares d5 to challenge White's center. Often leads to closed positions with pawn chains. Black's light-squared bishop can become problematic.

name: Caro-Kann Defense
description: A solid defense similar to the French but avoiding the problem of the light-squared bishop. Black prepares d5 with c6.
strategy: Prepare d5 to challenge the center while keeping the light-squared bishop free. Leads to solid, slightly passive positions for Black.

name: Queen's Gambit
description: Not a true gambit as the pawn is usually regained. White offers the c-pawn to gain central control and develop pieces actively.
strategy: White challenges Black's central pawn on d5, aiming to control the center with pieces rather than pawns. The c-pawn can usually be regained.

name: Queen's Gambit Declined
description: Black declines the gambit pawn and maintains central presence. One of the most solid defenses to 1.d4.
strategy: Black maintains d5 strongpoint and develops solidly. Often leads to a pawn chain with pawns on d5 and e6. Strategically rich positions.

name: King's Indian Defense
description: A hypermodern defense where Black allows White to build a strong pawn center, planning to attack it later. Named after Indian chess players who popularized it.
pgn: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 Bg7
strategy: Black fianchettoes the kingside bishop and allows White's pawn center, then strikes back with f5 or c5. Dynamic and aggressive counterplay.

name: Nimzo-Indian Defense
description: Named after Aron Nimzowitsch, this hypermodern defense pins White's knight and controls the center with pieces. One of the most respected defenses to 1.d4.
pgn: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4
strategy: Black pins the knight on c3 and is ready to double White's pawns if the knight is captured. Controls e4 and d5 squares with pieces.

name: English Opening
description: A flexible opening starting with c4, popular at all levels. Can transpose to many systems and allows White to avoid main-line theory.
strategy: Control the center with pieces and queenside pawns. Very flexible and can lead to reversed Sicilian structures or closed positions.

name: Réti Opening
description: A hypermodern opening named after Richard Réti. White develops the knight to f3 before committing pawns, controlling the center from a distance.
strategy: Flexible development allowing transposition to many systems. Controls e5 and d4 with pieces rather than pawns.

name: Scotch Game
description: An aggressive opening that immediately challenges Black's center. White opens the position early, leading to tactical play.
strategy: Open the center quickly and create immediate tactical threats. Leads to sharp, tactical positions with chances for both sides.

name: London System
description: A solid, system-based opening where White develops the bishop to f4 early. Popular at all levels for its simplicity and soundness.
strategy: Develop the bishop outside the pawn chain before playing e3. Solid and positional, avoiding heavy theory. Good for players who prefer systems.

name: Slav Defense
description: A solid defense to the Queen's Gambit. Black supports d5 with c6 while keeping the light-squared bishop free, unlike the Queen's Gambit Declined.
strategy: Maintain the d5 pawn while avoiding locking in the light-squared bishop. Solid and reliable, with good counterplay.

name: Pirc Defense
description: A hypermodern defense where Black fianchettoes the kingside bishop and allows White to build a strong center, planning counterplay later.
pgn: 1. e4 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. Nc3 g6
strategy: Allow White's pawn center and attack it later with pieces. Flexible pawn structure allows various plans.

name: Alekhine's Defense
description: Named after World Champion Alexander Alekhine, this provocative defense invites White to chase the knight and build a large pawn center, which Black aims to undermine.
strategy: Provoke White's pawns forward, then attack the overextended pawn center. High-risk, high-reward strategy.

name: Grünfeld Defense
description: A hypermodern defense developed by Ernst Grünfeld. Black allows White a strong pawn center and then attacks it with pieces.
pgn: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 d5
strategy: Strike at White's center immediately with d5. Complex and dynamic positions with chances for both sides.

name: Modern Benoni Defense
description: An aggressive counterattacking defense creating an asymmetric pawn structure. Black sacrifices space for piece activity and counterplay.
strategy: Create imbalanced positions with sharp tactical play. Black gets queenside pawn majority and piece activity in exchange for White's space advantage.

name: Dutch Defense
description: An aggressive defense where Black immediately stakes a claim on the kingside and e4 square. Leads to unbalanced positions.
strategy: Control e4 and prepare kingside expansion. Black accepts weakened king safety for active piece play.

name: Catalan Opening
description: A sophisticated opening combining d4 with a kingside fianchetto. Popular at the highest levels for its strategic richness.
strategy: Combine pressure on the center with the fianchettoed bishop's diagonal control. Subtle positional play.

name: Scandinavian Defense (Center Counter)
description: Black immediately challenges White's e4 pawn with d5. One of the oldest recorded openings, dating back to the 15th century.
strategy: Immediately challenge White's center, though the queen will need to move multiple times early. Solid but slightly passive for Black.

name: Budapest Gambit
description: An aggressive gambit where Black sacrifices a pawn for rapid development and attacking chances. Relatively rare but tricky.
strategy: Sacrifice the e5 pawn to gain time and piece activity. Black aims for tactical complications and quick development.

name: King's Gambit
description: One of the oldest openings, favored by Romantic-era players. White sacrifices the f-pawn for rapid development and attacking chances.
strategy: Sacrifice a pawn to open lines and attack Black's king. Leads to sharp tactical battles. Less common at the highest levels today.

name: Vienna Game
description: White develops the knight to c3 early, preparing f4 or supporting central play. Flexible and solid.
strategy: Support the center and prepare f4 thrust. More positional than the King's Gambit but with similar ideas.

name: Four Knights Game
description: A classical opening where both sides develop their knights symmetrically. Solid and straightforward.
pgn: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6
strategy: Develop all pieces before committing to a plan. Symmetrical but White retains a slight initiative.
